THE ALUMNI COUNCIL OF AMHERST COLLEGE
THE ALUMNI FUND
113 Class Agent
Henry S. Loonis,
42 Ularemont Ave.,
it, Vernon, N.Y.
May 26, 1936.
Dear Thirteeners:
Here's a treat for all of us --
a letter from Steamer Bixby.
is also noteworthy in heing a letter written in an airplane, probably the
first most of us have ever received.
April 20, 1936
Flying from Shanghai to Nanking.
Dear Dick:
During the last twelve months I have lived in a suitcase.
My
travels have carried me sometimes rather quickly from 20 below zero to
100 above.
From Peiping
on the north,
Chengtu on the west in the shadow
of the high mountains of Tibet, to Manila in the south.
One becomes
something of a Houdini packing
clothes for these extremes; woolens
and
whites,
dinner coat and mess jacket, all within the fifteen kilo (33 lbs)
weight limit.
My office has been a brief case in which my record of
never having the particular document needed is practically 100%.
During
this time I have neglected my correspondence but rolled up quite a mile-
age which I have just computed roughly as follows:
Airplane miles (mostly over China)
Steamship niles
Railroad
25,000
14,000
2,500
Automobile, bus, ricksha,
sedan chair and wheelbarrow have contributed a
miscellaneous and undetermined additional mileage,
The toughest travel
of all is up
country where there are no roads, and the narrow footpath
winding through the rice paddies permits only of transportation by
sedan
chair or wheelbarrow.
My experience with the latter did not last over 100
yards.
After jolting that far in that springless contraption I decided to
concluding that I'd get tired either way,
and walking offered the
advantage of being able to sit down at the end of my journey.
My
work in China has been largely as an aviation missionary for Pan
American Airways.
The latter company is a partner with
the
Chinese Govern-
ment in the
omership of China -ational Aviation Corporation, the routes
of which company cover an area almost the size of the United States.
The
C.N.A.C. uses American airplanes flown by American pilots on schedules that
call for more than a million airplane miles per annum.
Beyond attempting
to keep in touch with the C.N.A.C. my efforts have been directed toward as -
sisting to work out at this end some of the mechanical and political details
in connection with the trans-Tacific service.
I was in Manila when the
China Clipper arrived and you can imagine that I got quite a kick out of
seeing that ship land on the waters of Manila Bay.
Please make checks payable to Amherst Alumni Fund

-2-
I wish that my training in English literature had included a course
in modern fiction
so that I
could tell you many exciting adventures.
have been in cities under martial law which made the headlines in American
papers but I knew nothing about the situation until said American papers
reached here sone thirty days later.
ly travels have taken me over
section
which according to American press reports were ravished by war,
communists,
bandits, or floods,
but all I could see vere industrious and friendly
Chinese working in the fields.
Possibly the bandits know that I was for-
merly a banker and cleared out before my arrival.
An on my way back to Shanghai now in a Douglas D02 which left
Chengtu this morning and is scheduled to arrive in Shanghai at 5 p.m.
We are flying 170 miles per house, fourteen passengers mostly Chinese
plus a four man crew consisting of an American pilot,
Chinese co-pilot,
and radio operator and steward.
The fastest surface transportation between
Shanghai and Chengtu takes 16 days.
I was glad to find your several letters waiting for me a few days
ago when I returned from Manila - especially the one of March 16th about
I am hoping that we shall get together somewhere in this part
of the world.
If your Silver Senators would just leave us Chinese alone
See you in 138.
Regards,
Bix
Note: Since writing the above Mr. Bixby has left for the Philippines.
******
That "See you in '38"
sounds especially good.
Steamer's fourth
par graph fooled us the first time we read it
- of course you got it!
We refuse to believe that so nany miles around and over such a country
could be as devoid of adventure as he'a have us believe.
When we gather
"round that 113 dinner table in '33. I believe it's up to Bix to chip off
his shell of modesty and tell us a few tall stories.
Yours for the Alumni Fund,
Dick.
